body:
I just force pushed a rewritten version of this that's inline with the API that dhh suggested.  The relavent commit is [here](https://github.com/myronmarston/rails/commit/adb6ca31df847b682f258c9c8e402faf117cb61c).

There are a few edge cases that we need to iron out of the API.  Given the following models and observers:

```ruby
class ORM
  include ActiveModel::Observing
end

class Widget < ORM; end
class Budget < ORM; end
class WidgetObserver < ActiveModel::Observer; end
class BudgetObserver < ActiveModel::Observer; end
class AuditTrail < ActiveModel::Observer
  observe :widget, :budget
end
```

...how would you expect the following cases to work?

```ruby
Widget.observers.disable :all

# ...later
ORM.observers.enable :all
```

Should `WidgetObserver` and `AuditTrail` receive notifications for a `Widget`?  We've disabled them directly on `Widget`, but enabled _all_ observers on `ORM` at a later point.  It's a bit ambiguous what the behavior should be.

```ruby

Budget.observers.enable :audit_trail

# ...later
ORM.observers.disable :audit_trail
```

Again, it's a bit ambiguous: should `AuditTrail` receive notifications for a `Budget` or not?

Being able to enable/disable observers at different levels of the model class hierarchy sounds nifty in practice, but I'm concerned about these edge cases where there isn't a clear right answer (to me anyway).
